content: I wanted to run this code, on the git repo https://github.com/awslabs/shuttle . I have used cargo build to build the library. Now I wanted to run the example that is on the README file. Given that it is my first time seeing rust, I do not know much about what may be the problem. To be honest, I do not even know how to run the code that is in the README file. Should it be inside the main function? I am very confused, I tried to compile it several times with rustc but all sorts of errors keep showing up. Errors that do not recognize the shuttle library. However, I have already tried the flag -L to the library on the target/build folder and already tried to include the library with --extern as well and nothing seems to work. Please! Help me!
Hmmm, I have already run cargo build. But this library has no binaries. My question is, how do I use this library! I have no idea :(

I try to compile and the following keeps showing up 

# rustc example.rs
error: expected one of `!` or `::`, found `(`
 --> example.rs:4:22
  |
4 | shuttle::check_random(|| {
  |                      ^ expected one of `!` or `::```
you don't need to build the library separately. create a new project and add the library as dependency in cargo.toml
about that particular error, the code should go inside a function such as main
I also tried that, let me see that again
you might want to start with a hello world project first.
Oh okay! I DID IT! Thank you so much! :)
but if I have multiple programs, how can I choose which to compile. In my src I have main.rs and main1.rs but by default it always runs main.rs. How can I run main1.rs?

If you want more than one program in the same package, you have to move the main.rs for each program to the bin subdirectory of src and name it like the actual program. For example src/bin/foo.rs and src/bin/bar.rs for the programs foo and bar. You can then use cargo run --bin foo and cargo run --bin bar.
Oh nice, thanks a lot. That was what I wanted! ty!!!!
